issue.title: Allow using TomcatMetrics without `Manager` on the compilation classpath
issue.body:
See relevant Slack discussion: https://micrometer-metrics.slack.com/archives/C662HUJC9/p1698128026070889

Note: I'm not sure if it would be helpful to add a tiny bit of javadoc 🤷 

The two new constructors allow users to create an instance of `TomcatMetrics` without requiring them to have
`org.apache.catalina.Manager` on the compiliation classpath e.g. as a dependency with `provided` scope.

This is useful for for standalone Tomcat deployments where a war artifact is being deployed. In most cases the application code will not directly depend on Tomcat code but rather on javax/jakarkta APIs.

pull_request.body:
See relevant Slack discussion: https://micrometer-metrics.slack.com/archives/C662HUJC9/p1698128026070889

Note: I'm not sure if it would be helpful to add a tiny bit of javadoc 🤷 

The two new constructors allow users to create an instance of `TomcatMetrics` without requiring them to have
`org.apache.catalina.Manager` on the compiliation classpath e.g. as a dependency with `provided` scope.

This is useful for for standalone Tomcat deployments where a war artifact is being deployed. In most cases the application code will not directly depend on Tomcat code but rather on javax/jakarkta APIs.

comment.body: I wonder how to document this change, and where to put example code? WDYT?

pull_request.title: add support for Observation propagation in kotlin gRPC coroutine server
pull_request.body:
This commit contains changes that allow to capture current observation when using kotlin gRPC coroutine server.

In order to properly propagate current Observation to a coroutine server method, we need to propagate Observation as a context element by extending `CoroutineContextServerInterceptor`.

Moreover, current Observation needs to be somehow allowed to capture by `CoroutineContextServerInterceptor`. To do this, we need to open current Observation scope inside `ObservationGrpcServerInterceptor`. It is important to keep these two interceptors in a proper order - first, we need to open current Observation scope, and later create a context element based on it.

Fixes: #4218

pull_request.title: add support for Observation propagation in kotlin gRPC coroutine server
pull_request.body:
This commit contains changes that allow to capture current observation when using kotlin gRPC coroutine server.

In order to properly propagate current Observation to a coroutine server method, we need to propagate Observation as a context element by extending `CoroutineContextServerInterceptor`.

Moreover, current Observation needs to be somehow allowed to capture by `CoroutineContextServerInterceptor`. To do this, we need to open current Observation scope inside `ObservationGrpcServerInterceptor`. It is important to keep these two interceptors in a proper order - first, we need to open current Observation scope, and later create a context element based on it.

Fixes: #4218

issue.title: Deprecate DatadogMeterRegistry
issue.body:
The replacement option is detailed in https://docs.datadoghq.com/metrics/guide/micrometer/ by other otel/prometheus plugins

Related to https://github.com/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/pull/3329 follow up

comment.body:
Can certainly add some references here!

This registry has some bugs and documented a couple of those issues here: 
- https://github.com/micrometer-metrics/micrometer-docs/pull/225#issuecomment-1647962627
- https://github.com/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/issues/4056

We will be recommending against using the DatadogRegistry here as a result of the above issues. In addition given there are other compatible plugins that support open-source initiatives we contribute to, this makes sense for us to continue to invest in those (like otel). 

The otel and agent prometheus/openmetrics integrations are very well supported integrations and the agent is optimized to handle the failure modes and aggregations appropriate for Datadog customers.


So yes, for now it is still possible to use those HTTP endpoints directly, but we won't be continuing to support this integration directly as noted above. If you wish to keep it and close this, I'd probably recommend of the top of my mind: 
- fixing the issue of infinite loops PUTs to the metric metadata endpoints
- gracefully buffering and handling any failures at the API level to not drop data
- developing a way to exclude certain tags and exclude certain metrics for customers that are cost-conscious without requiring them make a code change.

comment.body:
Could you please help me to understand the intent of this? Is the HTTP API of Datadog deprecated? If not, why should the registry be?
I understand that Datadog supports multiple formats/protocols but HTTP is still available for the users, right?

pull_request.title: Datadog Dogstatsd support.
pull_request.body:
ref https://github.com/micrometer-metrics/micrometer-docs/pull/225 discussion

Make the smallest compatible change for users to migrate to dogstatsd approach. This still defaults to the prior API method currently. Many of our users already have the datadog-agent already installed collecting traces, logs and profiling information. This result in a positive performance and reliability benefit as your datadog-agent requires less network hops, and is configured to automatically handle edge related to retries and failure scenarios.  

This allows them to update their configuration as follows:

Instead of 
```
datadog.uri = https://api.datadoghq.com
datadog.apiKey = secret
```

For autodiscovery these environment variables should exist: https://github.com/DataDog/java-dogstatsd-client/blob/master/src/main/java/com/timgroup/statsd/NonBlockingStatsDClient.java#L53-L58
```
# note the 3rd `/` to satisfy java.net.URI
datadog.uri = discovery:///
```

For specifying exactly (example named pipe):
```
datadog.uri = unix:///var/run/datadog.sock
```

another example for udp to the listening port
```
datadog.uri = udp://localhost:8125/
```

issue.title: Datadog Dogstatsd support.

labels.name: waiting for team
labels.description: An issue we need members of the team to review

issue.body:
ref https://github.com/micrometer-metrics/micrometer-docs/pull/225 discussion

Make the smallest compatible change for users to migrate to dogstatsd approach. This still defaults to the prior API method currently. Many of our users already have the datadog-agent already installed collecting traces, logs and profiling information. This result in a positive performance and reliability benefit as your datadog-agent requires less network hops, and is configured to automatically handle edge related to retries and failure scenarios.  

This allows them to update their configuration as follows:

Instead of 
```
datadog.uri = https://api.datadoghq.com
datadog.apiKey = secret
```

For autodiscovery these environment variables should exist: https://github.com/DataDog/java-dogstatsd-client/blob/master/src/main/java/com/timgroup/statsd/NonBlockingStatsDClient.java#L53-L58
```
# note the 3rd `/` to satisfy java.net.URI
datadog.uri = discovery:///
```

For specifying exactly (example named pipe):
```
datadog.uri = unix:///var/run/datadog.sock
```

another example for udp to the listening port
```
datadog.uri = udp://localhost:8125/
```

comment.body:
👋 alrighty, followed this through at Datadog. We've published a guide after also reviewing other plugins offered by Micrometer. 

https://docs.datadoghq.com/metrics/guide/micrometer

I'm closing this PR, and will open a new PR to mark this Datadog plugin as deprecated, then will see y'all in a few months to remove the plugin entirely. 

Thank you for the feedback and reviews! 🙇

issue.title: Gauge does not update value in Gauge.builder

labels.name: question
labels.description: A user question, probably better suited for StackOverflow

comment.body:
> I don't think this is the right issue to discuss it but I'm not sure people would be happy if we would break their flow throwing an IllegalArgumentException. Logging on a `WARN` level might be better. Do you want to open a PR for this?

Yeah, I think you are right. Despite that call leads to non-working Gauge, it might be a minor issue for client code, while exception would break it completely. I'll try WARN and open a PR a bit later

issue.title: MeterRegistry.gauge not returning value reference of already existing Gauge

labels.name: usability
labels.description: A general issue for API usability

comment.body:
>what happen when the state object is removed by GC , on the application that use micrometer gauge ?

This should not happen since you keep a reference to the state, right? :)
If you don't and this will happen, `NaN` will be reported, you can try this out.

>update on the state object , how gauge knows to take the new value from the state object is there pulling interval gauge check for a new value ?

It depends on the registry. Whenever the `Gauge` is "pulled", it fetches the new value. For step registries this happens once per minute, for Prometheus, this happens every time you scrape.

>what still confuse me is why we have 2 diffrent ways to create gauge ..

We have two different ways to create every `Meter` not just `Gauge`.

>why we need both ways ? -- can we simplify this by having only single way to create guage , and a single way to update it value ?
why the 2 ways return different types ? one return the state object and the other return the gauge .

Creating a `Gauge` with a `Builder` is the way that ensures you can use all the features of a `Gauge` (description, unit, etc). The other way `registry.gauge(...)` is just a shortcut. Lots of users found it handy, please ignore it if you find it confusing. 

They return different types because:
- Returning the state is more convenient if you are using the shortcut, so that you can have a one-liner for registering the gauge and have the state.
- To be consistent to every other `register` methods, we return the instance which can be handy e.g. for testing, you can ignore it in other cases, see the docs:
>Generally the returned Gauge instance is not useful except in testing, as the gauge is already set up to track a value automatically upon registration.

>if some way is for test only put it under src/test directory as java standard project , so it will not be available to use for production runtime ... , and I would not put a "test" example on the official documentation ...

As the docs says it's mainly for testing purposes but I'm not sure I'm following what do you mean put it under `test`? The register method is necessary. You might not put a test example in the official docs but I would find it not a great user experience. Testing is important as well as the docs supporting you and showing you ways to test your code, you can find examples for this in a lot of other places in the Micrometer docs (or in other open source projects as well).

>can framework expose only single way to interact with gague for creationg and updating , and other api call to be private scope ?

I'm afraid no:
- It is actually used by users
- Every other `Meter` has these two ways (builder and shortcut)
- It would be a breaking change

issue.title: Gauge does not update value in Gauge.builder

labels.name: question
labels.description: A user question, probably better suited for StackOverflow

comment.body: I don't think this is the right issue to discuss it but I'm not sure people would be happy if we would break their flow throwing an IllegalArgumentException. Logging on a `WARN` level might be better. Do you want to open a PR for this?

issue.title: Add WARN message when OtlpMeterRegistry fails to publish metrics
issue.body: Experienced this bad behaviour while plugging my application to an APM; as I configured the bad endpoint, it answered me with `403` http status, yet nothing appeared in logs, as if everything was normal. I had to use debugger to see the status.

comment.body:
Nope, once it is merged to a maintenance branch the person who merged it should forward merge it to the other supported branches too. I've already taken care of forward merging and resolving the merge conflicts (as you noticed, the code changed a bit). This change is now available on `1.10.x`, `1.11.x`, and `main`, see https://github.com/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/commit/538ba6ac85599dc36284a12c5849333cf78c6023 and https://github.com/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/commit/32fe2c54006f330036f8cc181610a53852864ffb

You can try out any latest snapshot versions, e.g.: `1.12.0-SNAPSHOT`, it should contain your changes, thank you again for fixing this!

pull_request.title: Bump jersey2 from 2.40 to 2.41
pull_request.body:
Bumps `jersey2` from 2.40 to 2.41. Updates `org.glassfish.jersey.core:jersey-server` from 2.40 to 2.41 Updates `org.glassfish.jersey.inject:jersey-hk2` from 2.40 to 2.41 Updates `org.glassfish.jersey.test-framework.providers:jersey-test-framework-provider-inmemory` from 2.40 to 2.41 Updates `org.glassfish.jersey.test-framework.providers:jersey-test-framework-provider-jdk-http` from 2.40 to 2.41 Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting `@dependabot rebase`. [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-start) [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-end) ---
Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot show ignore conditions` will show all of the ignore conditions of the specified dependency - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)
